They seem fantastic and you wish you could propose to them right now if you could. Your food comes back, and you look at your smoked salmon, they aroma overwhelms your sense of smell in a paradise of cooked fish. You look at your beautiful date, your eyes lock and they know you two might be the ones for each other. You slice off a piece of fish and stick it into your mouth. You chew and you wonder, where do it go so right? Then poof, you become a cat. Turns out your date is allergic to cats and storms off, in disgust to yourself. A minute later, you're back to your oldself, wondering why the ♥♥♥♥ does fish in Torchlight 2 changes your species completely. 8/10 - too much fish - IGN

reviewText:
Torchlight II's story follows the events of the first game, although those who come into the game without playing the original will not be missing much. Players create their own hero from one of four new classes, and are tasked with preventing one of the original heroes, who has been corrupted, from bringing ruin to the world. The story serves its purpose of giving players a reason to head off for the next quest goal but for the most part is pretty negligible, with the exception of a few rare quests of interest.

The options for character creation are expanded from the original; there are now four classes and each class has options for its gender, hair, and face. Pets also make a return, with a number of new creatures added. The pets are welcome companions, assisting the player by participating in combat, learning spells, being able to summon minions of their own, and even travelling back to town to sell loot and buy potions so the player doesn't have to.

Basic gameplay follows the template used by other isometric and top-down action RPGs. Players move using the left mouse buttons and click on enemies to attack. There are a wide number of skills and spells available, with numerous ways to activate them through various hotkeys and on-screen icons. The game allows for a lot of variety in builds and play styles, with each level up providing points to add to attributes and to upgrade and learn skills. Also provided is a lot of variety in equipment with no class restrictions, with the exception of some unique loot, although a number of skills require a certain weapon type. Loot in the game is plentiful, but fortunately the game makes it very easy to compare picked up loot with that currently equipped and to switch it into the pet's inventory so it can be quickly sold. There will always be the occasional pause midway through a dungeon to conduct some inventory management, however, outside of these pauses the pacing is quick and keeps the action going at an engaging level.

The dungeons are randomly generated in terms of overall layout, but specific areas like boss arenas are preset. This means that when playing multiplayer or a new game plus, it isn't a matter of simply retreading old routes, and the highly enjoyable exploration experience that the dungeons provide is always there. There is always a danger of such generated dungeons becoming generic and repetitive but it is pleasing to report that the danger has been negated as well as could be hoped for. A number of tougher enemies and special challenge zones litter Torchlight II's areas, providing fairly regular breaks from the usual fodder (who can still pack a punch if players aren't paying attention) and making sure things don't get too repetitive. The player character can become briefly stuck in a crowd that's difficult to maneuver out of, but these situations are rare and typically caused by charging in too wildly rather than through any fault of the game.

With the exception of Hardcore mode, where death is permanent, players can respawn without too much consequence. A percentage of gold can be paid in order for the deceased character to reappear either where they died or at the map entrance. Alternatively they can respawn back in town for free. There are four difficulty options to choose from plus a toggle for the aforementioned Hardcore mode. The Normal difficulty is a decent, but not especially challenging, level for newcomers, so experienced Torchlight players will likely want to jump immediately into Veteran.

Difficulty in multiplayer is handled well, with monsters increasing in toughness depending on the number of players. While it's certainly not necessarily to enjoy what Torchlight II has to offer, there can be no denying the enjoyment of playing the game with others and it adds a more than welcome dimension to the game. Those afraid of having their loot taken by comrades need not fear, as players get their own sets of loot visible only to them. There is plenty of postgame content for players to sink their teeth into after completing the twenty hour or so main campaign, either by tackling one of the main postgame dungeons or by starting a new game plus, which keeps the player's progress but levels up all the opponents to match. New game plus might disappoint some, as it isn't possible to notch up the difficulty, so those hoping for a greater challenge in the main story will need to start a new character. The game has also been created with the modding community in mind, so even if Runic's postgame options run out there will likely be plenty of fan-made offerings.

Visually the game looks great, even on less powerful computers, and for the most part runs very smoothly. The art style is great, the environments are all nicely varied, and the UI is clear and easy to use. Even when hidden behind terrain, it's easy to see where the character is and to click on enemies thanks to a coloured outline that appears for any combatant potentially obscured. Spells and skills are all beautifully animated, and it's incredibly satisfying to see enemies explode upon being finished off with a critical hit. Voice acting is generally rare, but it doesn't feel like the game is missing much without it. The key quest givers and few animated cutscenes are voiced, and it's functional for getting the next task across, but there's not enough of it to have any major effect and can be easily ignored without anything being missed.

For me Torchlight II was an immensely enjoyable experience from start to finish. The game is more than welcoming for both fans of the original and newcomers to the series and is high amongst the better gaming experiences I've had this year. It might not bring anything particularly new to the genre, but those who choose to pick it up will be provided with superb value for their money.

Highly Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
This game is just neat - it can be a Sunday hack'n'slash passtime, and it can be a real grinder. I am happy I finally have a computer I can play T2 with ease, as I spend many hours with it's prequel and was quite hyped to play this one.
I love the multum of possibilities of seemingly narrow range of heroes, and I'm all about doing those hybrid characters.
Two things are a big minus to me: firstly, building a successful summoner class takes quite a lot of time in higher difficulty modes. Secondly, Act III monsters are just cheap (besides the epic boss fights) and take away much of the lore's momentum - so if you feel doubts in Act III, keep pushing until You reach those Dwarven ruins. Either way, I think it's very easy to ommit how wonderful of a universe Torchlight has, with it's little details that can slip your attention if you play too fast. It's a lore very prone to development and alteration, and I'm also happy to see some very lore-friendly mods.
Awesome game worth a recommendation!

reviewText:
I won't lie; it took me a bit of time to actually get into Torchlight II; I didn't feel like it had a hugely compelling start to the game, the art style felt a little unpolished, the combat seemed a bit dull.  Nothing really jumped out at me, even for 11 levels of gameplay.

Imagine my surprise when I actually upped the difficulty from Normal to Veteran, and installed the Synergies Mod.  Now, it's tough to put down!

Torchlight II comes highly recommended.  The game itself is really pretty solid, and once you up the difficulty, the gameplay actually becomes compelling and fun.  You'll be on the edge of your seat when the fights get tougher and tougher, and it feels more rewarding.

reviewText: Do you like Diablo?  Do you like multi-player?  Hell, do you like good games?  If you said yes to any of those, then this game is for you. The length of the game, the locations, the story, the combat, the music, etc.  Everything is better in this phenomenal sequel.  Torchlight II is an action/ adventure RPG much like an offline MMO.  Your character levels, you choose talent traits, and you grow in abilities.  This game has figured out everything that was important and mastered them.  I had a blast playing Torchlight II both single player and with friends.  I would give this game a 9/10.

reviewText:
An incredibly simplistic Diablo-esque ARPG with Steam Workshop support to possibly enhance replayability.
Before starting the game you're given the option to start the vanilla version and the Workshop supported version. You can move your vanilla character to the Workshop version however the character you save your progress with Workshop mods on will no longer be allowed back to the vanilla game.

The game's difficulties range from Casual, Normal, Veteran, & Elite where the differences in these are that the gold drops are lower and enemy damage & health are increased the higher the setting. In Elite mode the game doesn't just feel harder, it feels like more like an endurance because I found myself constantly having to hit, run, heal, hit, run, heal, and repeat wasting more time than I should be wasting if I was on Veteran because everything on Elite can kill you in a flash and it doesn't help that the baddies take a hell of a lot longer to kill because of the artificial difficulty of increased baddie HP.
There's a an option to check whether or not you want to activate Hardcore" mode for the rest of a character's playthrough where all it means is that one death means you can't play that character anymore so this is really for those who like to be more pressured into being careful to stay alive.

Unlike the first game you now have a choice of 4 classes however the previous classes have been removed though they all use similar & new equipment as the first. Each class has a handful amount of unique skills but I've found that I was really only putting points in an incredibly low amount of them all the way up to the end-game & max level
recommended: leaving probably 80% of the skills without even a single point placed. Though effective this leaves the combat to show how simplistic its action is which all-in-all is just hit
voteText: & maybe heal. No matter how fancy the skills you've put the points on it's still just run
helpfulPercent: attack
votesHelpful: run
votesTotal:
and possibly heal up with a potion or a spell so should heavy damage be taken. You can only "respec" the last 3 skills you've placed points on so you can do a small bit of testing to find out what suits your preference.

The controls for the game are typical isometric ARPG style with the all too likely-to-become problematic mouse-to-move and extensively rebindable keys with the exception of the mouse buttons being unrebindable. I found that the mouse controls can often be wonky; when I try to move to the opposite side of a crowd of baddies to get away from them for some reason the character would sometimes move to them and attack instead despite the mouse being nowhere near them. During critical situations it becomes an incredible nuisance.

Though very diverse in skins

commentsCount: & sounds almost all enemy attacks are similar to one another so I found that fighting just became repetitive with the exception of having some new skills to toy with but still overall becomes the same hit & run rule in combat. reviewText:
Wow, I'm actually genuinely surprised that I have not yet written a review for this wondrous game. Or maybe I should put it wanderous? Yes, I know it's not an actual word, continue on.

Torchlight II is a game of deep, enthralling exploration and the subsequent battles for glory, fame, and of course, loot drops that follow throughout this excursion. You must choose a character to harness your abilities from the four available classes: Outlander - Ranged weapons; Embermage - More spells than Harry Potter; Berserker - Right up in your face, meat slicing action; Engineer - A combo of ranged/up-front-and-personal weapons with robots. Each role serves a purpose whether you are in a party of 1 or a whole crew of 4. I personally played with a friend who manned Outlander while I played Engineer.

Throughout my journey, I roasted, toasted, grinded, and gibbed more monsters than I can recall and had a blast quite literally. I will mention that I had not played Torchlight I or any other top-down RPG before playing Torchlight II. As an introduction to this fantastic genre, Torchlight II touched all the bases any game should: Engaging and exciting gameplay; balanced classes, enemies, and loot; and content that progresses and evolves to a greater level by the end of the game. Throw in a soundtrack that perfectly matches the ambiance and you've got a smoldering fire of a game.

It is important to note that I had a friend to play with during my adventure, so this may influence one's opinion on this game. I am considering going through and playing it again, the only thing holding me back is my circadian rhythm - I'm not quite sure it's ready for a re-run.

Final Ratings
Gameplay: 10/10 - Never was bored, definitely stayed up way too late.

Storyline: 7/10 - Not too hard to follow but I probably would've had an easier time had I played Torchlight I.

Combat: 7/10 - Not confusing, easy to learn, a multitude of abilities to keep each encounter varied. I blasted through the enemies on Normal on my first run-through. I would recommend playing on Hard as the final boss seemed easier than expected. On Normal it's easy to get hyper-leveled if you love grinding enemies.

Scary? Nope - Cartoony sense of fun

Pop-Ups: None, it's top-down silly!

Graphics: 7.5/10 - Cartoony and fun

100% Achievements: Not easy. Requires multiple playthroughs. Definitely need some luck too for a couple.

Singleplayer: N/A - Did not play by myself.

Replayability: High replay value, I definitely see myself going through this game at least another time. Not to mention, there are copious amounts of scenarios to do after the main story line.

Multiplayer: 10/10 - Wholeheartedly recommend playing with a friend or friends.

reviewText:
Torchlight II vs Diablo review

Nope, you know what? We're not going to go about reviewing this game that way - not because they're not comparable or not in the same genre, but because it's like pitting apples vs oranges, or Star Trek vs Star Wars.  Just because two games, shows, or fruits share a few features doesn't mean you can really place one over the other.

So, where to begin...

Torchlight II offers so, so much to fans of classic dungeon crawler ARPG's.  It offers 4 dynamic classes with 3 skill trees which allow you to mix and match skills at will; attribute points for stats that are all useful to every character in their own way; secret rooms usually accessed through puzzles; epic boss battles; gigantic world chests that require a key that drops from a specific mob; portals to other dimensions filled with loot; both shared and personal stashes; and - last but not least - pets.

Pets are a really unique addition to Torchlight II that satisfy the loot hoarder in each of us.  While out adventuring, your pet will carry all of your unwanted loot back to town.  In addition to this, they will assist you in battle, cast spells, and go shopping for basic supplies.  No feeding necessary!

Something else that's both unique and awesome about this game is its mod-friendly attitude.  It offers a very helpful mod kit for any who are interested in expanding Torchlight II's horizons, and actively supports said mods with online play.

Speaking of online play, Torchlight II is an  excellent  game to play with your friends!  Don't forget, if you guys are playing a modded version of the game you HAVE to not only be subscribed to the same mods but have the mods in the same load order as well.

Torchlight II is fantastic to play solo.  Nearly all of my 200+ hours in this game have been spent alone, tearing through the wilderness of Torchlight.  From level 1 to level 100, gameplay is fresh and challenging.  Difficulty can be changed as needed between 4 difficulty settings, and hardcore characters are an option.

Before I end this review, I must add that the music is FANTASTIC.  It is by far some of the best music I've heard from an ARPG's OST.  Even if you decide not to purchase the game, definitely visit YouTube and give its music a listen - although, it is definitely better when experienced in the settings meant for it ;)

reviewText:
If you like crawlers if game might be one for you.Smashing through mobs,enjoying a challenge, lovely environments,great boss fight ,armor/weapon sets,lots of loot,powerful mod tools ,and offline/online co-op make this game a great crawler choice.It comes with all the standard dungeon crawler trimmings so you will be more than full.The game has lots of graphic options,key binding controls, and built in multi-screen support. You can play this game well enough on a laptop with an intergrated card or on a beefy desktop machine.Some have claimed they got it to run on their tablets as well.

There are 4 classes each that are non traditional but play like hybrids of traditional classes melded together.Engie (Paladin/Warrior/bot summoner) ,Outlander(Gunslinger/Ninja), Beserker(Crazed Monk/Beastman),& Embermage (Element Assault/Support) sorry no dedicated healers in this game.You are free to pick and choose what skills(active and/or passive) you will use.Six player is the default online max,but mods can increase this.

The game itself has an overworld and dungeons littered throughout it.Throughout it you will find tons of loot,mobs,champion enemies,bosses,traps,and hidden secrets to find. The presentation for the areas are well done and add to making your travels more enjoyable.You have a pet in game that has basic attacks,can be used to buy/sell things for you while you battle on.

The story of the game countines from a small time after the ending of events in Torchlight 1 but you do not need to know anything of the story to get into Torchlight 2. The ending of torchlight 1 makes up the story of whats happening in TL2 which you will be told.The story is interesting enough if you wish to follow it , but not required to play through the game like most crawlers.

A warning though, the online portion in this game can be either great or a bit laggy. This I believe due to the lack of dedicated server hosting.The game has a ingame lobby which is held on a dedicated server,but hosted games are pc to pc.So make sure whomever hosts has a good connection

reviewText: Torchlight 2 consumes hours on end of your life with its unique design and interesting animation! Combat is a thrill when you are able to pummel your enemies with spells and abilities. It's always simple to tell when there is room to improve your character! Unlike what blizzard has to offer in its newest Diablo game (Diablo 3), TL2 requires YOU to do the math with dynamic gameplay. The game has a more advanced feeling when you are required to compare items and weigh your decision carefully (ie; When to socket, What to use, Which enchantments, and so forth). The classes are amazing and what really makes the game is the lack of limit unlike in previous dungeon crawlers. Torchlight 2 is one of my favorites now, and i highly recommend to anybody that has the courage to face a new ARPG!

reviewText:
This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Torchlight 2 skip to Results and read from there.

Runic Games provides us with an invigorating spin to your standard RPG game with dynamic evolving dungeons. Unlike most AI managers Torchlight II doesn’t just update enemy spawns, but also creates new terrain with each experience.

Story:
Torchlight II takes place in a time far beyond the reign of Ordrak the daemon who caused dismay to the little town of Torchlight; yet, despite his fall the corruption he spread was not lost. An evil alchemist takes up his power and destroys the town of Torchlight as your quest begins to bring civility back to reality. You progress through the various worlds of the Torchlight universe from various towns in unique environments from mountains, desserts, tundra’s, and swamps. There is no end to the evil that Ordrak spirit has spread.

Campaign:
Torchlight II is separated into four Acts: Estherian Steppes, Mana Wastes, Grunnheim, and Broken Mines. Unlike in the first Torchlight the second offers multiple towns which provide unique experiences that help evolve the game. Each town offers unique merchants that evolve with the difficulty of the game providing better items and new elements to the mix. The campaign, depending on your play style, can easily last up to 30-hours. The game has a good difficulty curve which allows the game to readily scale to the player’s level. Plus by utilizing the randomly generated experience the game offers players can also out-level their environments if they feel like they the game is too difficult.

Gameplay:
Torchlight II expands on the original by providing four rather than three unique experiences: The Engineer, Outlander, Berserker, and Embermage.
The Engineer is a melee class which utilizes heavy armor and has abilities to summon various support style minions. My main complication with the Engineer is that this task is clearly designed around being a support/tank role, but has not taunting abilities. This essentially makes team work relatively difficult as you cannot get your enemies to readily focus on you.
The Outlander similar to the Vanquisher is a rained base class that utilizes mainly dexterity based building. This class offers trapping, dual wielding, and high speed attacks. The design of the outlander makes it great for kiting and boss fights, but relatively poor against swarms of enemies.
The Beserker follows your typical fighting class by utilizing melee weapons with high speed combat and not being reliant on armor. The unique playstyle of the Beserker allows you to summon wolves to your aid, throw down with massive melee damage, and utilize frost and lightning buffers to enhance your combat. The beserker does great with live recovery items and high health units, but can easily get swarmed by low hit point units.
Finally the Embermage, which as you can tell is a magic class champion. Focusing on mostly magic attributes the Embermage utilizes spellcasting to defeat their enemies. This is the only class I didn’t beat the game with, but from my understanding they are incredibly useful for supporting roles and are as strong as they are in mana. Mostly focusing on mana stealing items and mana pots this class fights at range and doesn’t do well in swarms.

Sadly Torchlight II did not adjust the control mechanics that are utilized through Torchlight I. The champion is still controlled entirely by the users mouse. Moving the character and attaching are both controlled by holding the left click of the mouse, rather than moving with the keyboard and fighting with the mouse. On Melee classes this is fine, but on ranged classes more than not you run into battle because you click next to an enemy; because your champion ran into battle they are then killed and your kiting has failed.

Hints:
>Make sure to get the spell that allows you to drop a town portal, drop this in every dungeon to make sure you do not have to fight your way back due to random generated dungeons.
>Once a player leaves a dungeon there is approximately a 20-minute timer before regenerating, Meaning if you are in a dungeon that has multiple floors you may have to fight your way back through if you die closer to the end without a portal to get you back.
>Playing as a group causes more enemies to spawn meaning playing with your friends doesn’t change the difficulty.
>Make sure to put items on your pet. Your pet can hold two spells, two rings, and a necklace.  By putting in the proper sockets and maximizing your pet effectively can make for a great tank and an amazing support.
>I found the best spells for your pet are “Frost” and “Heal All” this allows your pet to slow enemies and heal the team.
>Send your pet back to town when you get the chance, this sells the items it is holding and heals it to full health.


Results:
I personally played Torchlight II before completing Torchlight I. This game provides a unique experience somewhere in between Diablo III and Spelunky. Through randomly generated dungeons and it’s combat experience Torchlight II is guaranteed to provide your typical RPG style player with an enjoyable dynamic experience; although the generated dungeons don’t provide much replay value with the same class they are just a touch unique enough to make playing each other class fun and original. Even though I purchased this game on sale I would still recommend it at full price.

Pros:
+Four unique classes that provide diversifying experiences through their unique playstyles and skill trees.
+Multiplayer cooperative experience
+Pets which provide benefit to the player as either a way to sell items, a some-what tank, or even a healer.
+Two types of leveling for a character: Experience and Fame. Fame allows you to level only your abilities, while experience gives you five points to level your characters base stats and a point to level abilities.
+Dynamic environment that evolves and changes each play through.
+Fun bosses that offer interesting battles that vary based on swarming, spell dodging, terrain shifting, and time management.

Cons:
-Character controls that sadly cannot be adjusted. You must control your character with the mouse for both movement and combat, which causes a lot of times where you die due to poor controls rather than skill.
-Random generated dungeons occur on time base rather than if the player quits. This means if you are in an areas sub-dungeon it is possible the first floor regenerates. Ultimately this means if you die you must start over again.
-Fishing provides your pet with cool skin/ability changes, but typically is more cumbersome than it’s worth. Similar to the first Torchlight you just simply wait as a circle expands and retracts until it hits the middle for a fraction of a second where you must click the reel in button.

reviewText:
I'm always on the lookout for new ARPG's to play and so my quest led me to Torchlight II.

I really LIKE this game! There is a nice art style to the game that's quite similar to World of Warcraft. There are plenty of enemies to slaughter and looks great when gibbed. As you would expect this game is full of loot to gather, sell or hoard. When on quests you are not alone, you have a choice of pet companions upon character creation, amongst them a headcrab from Half-Life... a headcrab! There are many references to other games and films, which are nice to see and find. Story is ok to follow but nothing intricate or ground-breaking.

This is a great ARPG for the casual gamer.

reviewText: This is top down action role playing at its best.  Its what D3 should of been.  There are 4 classes (more with mods) that are pretty fun to play, and you can play them in various ways.  There is not alot of restrictions on the classes and what they can use.  Each one has 3 skill trees, which you can use any tree as long as your the at the level requirement for it, your not restricted to 1 tree, you can put points anywhere.  The item drops are fun, you get plenty of rare items.  Story, I never follow the story line so I cant comment on that (same for all games).  End Game is either playing through the game again with monsters leveled up, or using maps in the Mapworks.   Maps you can purchase at a vendor and they all have stats, like +% Fire Damage, +% More Gold, and/or +% Damage for Monsters.  I've only played an Embermage lvl 100 NG++, and a 56 Beserker.\n\n9/10

reviewText:
Alright so, this game has many pros and 1 con.
Check it out:
Nice story, one of the playable classes in the first game has turned into the main villian of this game. What a twist. And the general story of this one is pretty interesting.
Nice gameplay, Instead of having a few infinite boring dungeons like the first one, this game offers an open world feel where you come across dungeons here and there. Really nice. The vanilla version offers 4 creative classes that you can play in many ways. A LOT of loot to collect and everything is just fun. AND this one has multiplayer where you can get kicked from games by people who don't speak English! I bet you're convinced now. But if the game itself doesn't satisfy you, there are countless of mods through workshop!
Nice graphics, looks better than the first one and kind of gives a World of Warcraft art feel. I like it and you don't need an amazing system to run it. If my flea market 50 dollar can run this pretty much lag free, I'm pretty sure you guys can run it.
What else is there to cover? Pretty much everything is great about it, one of my favorite dungeon crawlers.

oh yeah, the con: 4 of the achievements are unachieveable, they're broken. Runic knows this and refuses to remove them purposely. IN FACT, they are using these broken achievements as a marketing tool. During one of the steam sales they changed the name of these achievements to Queued for Removal" to draw in the completionist to buy this game. But right after the sale ended
date: you want to know what happened? They changed the name of the achievements right back to "Unachieveable". They could easily remove these achievements no problem. Damn you Runic and your..and your gay parties.\n\nBut yeah that's about it
hoursPlayed: this game is perfect and I'd recommend buying it.\n\nTL;DR: GG"

reviewText:
I will echo many other reviews and start by saying: If you liked Diablo 2, you should really enjoy Torchlight 2.

In fact, at times I felt this game was almost too derivative. Both games have 4 Acts. Each Act has its own hub town, bosses, unique geographic setting and a narrated cinematic at each Act's beginning. Even the storyline has a lot of similarities.

With all that said, Torchlight 2 clearly wasn't designed to be novel. Instead they set out to do the dungeon crawler genre really, really well. And they succeeded.

The gameplay is fast paced, addictive, loot filled fun. Everything about this game is user friendly. It's easy to get to and from town; your pet can easily be sent to sell off your unwanted spoils while you keep adventuring; even playing on the Veteran difficulty I almost never had to buy potions or magic scrolls; quests are clearly marked on the map, never leaving you wondering what to do next; when you die you have the option to respawn in town for free or lose gold but respawn near where you died.

My main criticism is likely to be experienced differently by each person who plays Torchlight 2. I started to get bored with the game about 3/4ths through the story mode. This is common for me with games of this type. I should note that I played to the end of the game fully in single player. Your mileage may vary particularly if you plan to play online with friends.

I'll close by saying if you did NOT like Diablo 2, or other highly rated dungeon crawlers, do not be swayed by all the positive reviews this game has gotten. Trust your gut; I suspect that the type of person that will enjoy this game already knows that they will enjoy it.

reviewText:
This is gonna get complicated. Ok, let's get this out of the way: the game is quite good. I've played 75 hours, Steam tells me, and I did enjoy them - at least modded. Unmodded, the record would probably be more like 6. There are some great mods that hugely improve what's already a solid base. The reasons I can't recommend it, though, are complex.

First off, it's the feel. I do not like the game's aesthetic. It's very cartoonish and detracts from the feel I'd want. The story is forgettable at best, a confusing afterthought with no thought put into it whatsoever at worst, which I suppose you could expect from an ARPG, but... why? It's a spiritual successor to Diablo, right? Diablo 2 especially had a really interesting story. The setting was great, with Good and Evil both presented as Bad, some cool ideas and history, and even genuine characters! With personality! It was also very good-looking for the time, with a dark, interesting aesthetic, rather than the goofy one here that I personally dislike. Admittedly, that's a matter of taste, but this isn't meant to be objective. And the characters are just... nonexistant. The most interesting thing about the setting are a race that's left their bodies behind and are now just animated suits of armor, basically. Which are never really explored anyway.

Modded, though, I'd say it's worth the price except for one thing: the existence of Path of Exile.

In a vacuum? Sure, it's fun. $20 of fun, especially if you're looking for a time sink. Compared to Diablo 3? Yeah, certainly buy this. Compared to Path of Exile, which is free, incredibly innovative, gorgeous, dark, actually has an interesting story, and is simply more fun (in my opinion)? Why bother?

And, frankly, even today I'd call it as much fun as Diablo 2: Lord of Destruction at best, at least if you care much about story, atmosphere, or aesthetic. If you don't, and just want gameplay and can seriously ignore all that, go for it. If you do, well there's Path of Exile, or... so how much is Diablo 2: LoD now?

It should also be mentioned I rather resent the game because I preordered it due to the promise of the toolset, GUTS, being made available soon" (and even
recommended: "very soon") after release. Not relevent to you

reviewText: Beyond the town of Torchlight lies a world shrouded in adventure and mystery. Guardian-warrior Syl appears in a prophetic dream, summoning the player to the Estherian Steppes. There, you meet with the Destroyer and soon venture across the continent of Vilderan, an exotic frontier besieged by forces of evil. A discovery unfolds, that the Alchemist, following his conquest of dark ember, disappeared on his quest to defeat the unknown corrupted force responsible for destroying the mystical race of Estherians. Aided by Syl, the remaining Estherian Guardians, and clues left behind by the missing Alchemist, you will find yourself battling a powerful enemy that threatens to unravel the elements of the entire world. In other words this is a great MMO RPG based on the MMO RPG classic FATE. I highly recomend this game

reviewText:
Torchlight 2 is an excellent sequel to an already outstanding game. Runic Games upped the stakes and 3 years after the release of the first game they came out with a more ambitious, more colourful, more varied and more enjoyable sequel.

Whilst the game features the same gameplay-style as its predecessor, notable (and brand new) elements are the availability of multiplayer and the extended modding capabilities.

Also, the four playable classes introduced in this episode are brand new and those present in the first game do not return. These classes offer the options to create several builds so fully getting to know the characteristics of a class requires multiple walkthroughs.

Pets also return (but with more options) and instead of the retirement of our characters we have the newgame+ mode. Also, a hardcore mode for die-hard fanatics.

Torchlight 2 is a must for Diablo fans. But do bear in mind that this is similar to Diablo 2 and not to its latest installment.

reviewText:
!!! TORCHLIGHT 2 !!!

Torchlight II is incredibly polished though I’ve found a few bugs here and there. It’s quite apparent that Runic spent a lot of time making sure that TL2 was ready to ship, something an independent studio has the luxury to do. It shows but there is work to be done to ironed out. To be frank, Torchlight 2 brings very little that's utterly new to the scene. It improves what’s been done before and makes it damned fun to play, definitely a saving grace. The two terrific asides to the notion above is the addition of the Random Dungeon Generator and the modding tools (even though

The single biggest and best improvement in Torchlight 2 is the addition of cooperative multiplayer. Runic listened to its fans after the original was released and made sure to include it in the sequel. You can tie your Steam account to your Runic account, choose the Internet option and see a lobby filled with games of all levels. Games can be named and given a password for private play or they can be open for anyone to join. As with most lobby type games, you can create a friends list and even filter games to only see games created by your buddies. In addition, games can be created that only friends can join.

Sad to say, but there just inst enough good things to say about Torchlight 2, even with the minor issues it does have. It is one of the most refreshingly fun action RPGs i've played in a very long time. Its predecessor was lots of fun too, But with the addition of multiplayer, the dungeon generator and the modding tools, the series becomes something special, something different on the scene and something worthy of your time and money to play.

- XeroSyphon

reviewText:
Game: Torchlight 2
Genre: RPG-Adventure
Developer: Runic Games
System: PC (Steam)
Total Score: 92/100
Value Score: 9.2/10

• Story: 7/10
o Torchlight 2's storyline picks off where Torchlight 1 ended. The Alchemist which was one of the main characters from the first game ended up becoming corrupt thanks to the effects of the last game's villain's heart. Now you who will play as a new character will have to hunt him down and save the world from whatever he is planning to. You'll be going through several towns, dungeons and all sorts of terrain to find the Alchemist. The storyline overall is a bit generic but the side stories and side quests and their importance plays a interesting role within the overall game.

• Characters: 7/10
o Characters from the first game do appear in this game but barely do you interact with them, other than that all the enemies in the game and the characters you meet afterwards are all new but do not hold much substance like other RPGs however the amount of characters especially when it comes to enemy designs is quite huge. The player themselves can also create their own character, choosing the gender, skin color, hair appearance and color amongst other tidbits though you would not probably notice a difference due to the fact the armor you get in the game would make it to where you probably would not care about how you make your character look.

• GamePlay: 10/10
o Torchlight 2's gameplay is very similar to Torchlight 1's with a few new additions. For one, you have the choice to play as 4 different classes: Berserker which is best for close quarters combat and has insane speed, Mechanic is which best as a support character and as a secondary attacker, Outlander which is best with long range attacks and finally Ember Mage which is the equivalent of a Wizard in TL2 which is pretty much self explanatory. Depending on what you choose for skills and equipment you can build your character up to different builds and uses such as having a offensive ember mage instead of a magic user. The user interface is very similar to TL1 which is heavily inspired by Diablo and World of Warcraft. You have access to different features in towns and throughout different dungeons such as the ability to gamble for items, power up items through enchantments (which do not break or de-enchant anymore), to fuse items. Along with that the usual item shop, weapon/armor shop, and the special item/magic shop as well. There are a lot of side quests along with the story's main quests. One of the biggest additions to the game from its predecessor is Online Multiplayer, many people have anticipated this feature and wanted so much from the first game will now get to enjoy it in this game as up to 6 players can connect to each other on TL2's public servers or make their own private server via LAN. All items are exclusive to each player, no player will see another player's item or treasure (this is to prevent any disputes for loot).

• Graphics: 10/10
o Torchlight 2's graphical interfaces, environment and character sprites designs are similar to the first game but further improved with using current technologies making it one of the best looking 2Dish helicopter view games ever made.

• Sound: 10/10
o Torchlight 2 uses voiceovers throughout the majority of the game's main storyline, there will be instances where you will hear voices from other npcs and from yourself during dungeon raids. Torchlight 2's sound effects are both a combination of new effects to the game and uses some effects from the first game. The voiceovers are pretty well done for the characters and the sound effects go nicely with the environment and during the action sequences of cutscenes and battles.

• Music: 8/10
o Torchlight 2 uses similar style of music that the first game used, calm soothing orchestral type music is used mostly in the game, most of the parts of the game it has that unique Star Wars like epic feeling in the background whenever you travel the terrain or go through a town conversing with the NPCs. The developers were also kind enough to allow players to actually have access to the full OST of the game via the Game's folder on the PC, so enjoy the whole OST of Torchlight 2 on your portable mp3 player.

• Length: 10/10
o Torchlight 2's length is possibly its second greatest aspect if not the gameplay, the game's main storyline by itself should take you no more than 20 hours and additional 5-10 hours' worth of grinding and side questing on the side. If that isnt enough, you may do multiple playthroughs with friends or with other characters to see the world of Torchlight through different experiences which of course adds massive appealing value to this aspect.

• Replay Value: 10/10
o One of the best things about most western games is the replay value and TL2 is no exception. The Online multiplayer experience by itself adds great value to the replay value through different experiences and difficulties available for you to choose from. Once you finish the game, you get access to a endless random dungeon which takes you to random environments so you can explore thoroughly for additional treasures and other items. Along with that to add even more value, they added a New Game+ which allows you to play the game all over again using the same character but with a more difficulty twist to the gameplay.

• Player Value: 10/10
o Overall Torchlight 2 expands over the first one and improves in pretty much in every way, despite some network issues it may have from time to time, players will surely enjoy the multiplayer experiences and if not they can dabble on the single player experience which like the multiplayer can be experienced through different difficulties. You have a pretty decent customization options for your characters and can easily build up any class in any possible way. The graphical details have improved from the game, the sound effects and music are kept the similar to the first game. Pretty much TL2 consists of all the good aspects of TL1 plus more.

reviewText:
I remember the day when I had bought this game when it was on a Steam sale. I had a couple of dollars left and I wanted to spend the money on something that interested me. I had bought Torchlight II and haven't touched it for quite some time, since I was not an active Steam user back then. When I first played it, I immediately regretted not playing this sooner.

Torchlight II is, to put in the simplest words, an amazing game. The product is a highly polished game with many surprises hidden around every corner.  The world is randomly generated every time you start a new character/start New Game+ on an existing character so every experience will be a highly unique one. The game really gets to the point; you can immediately delve into the fun of clicking on monsters and annihilating them with your weapons/skills.

As is said in many other reviews, the story is definitely lacking. I had attempted to follow the story when I first started playing but ended up not caring for the story at all. If you are into an RPG with a rich story, this game is not for you.

Gameplay-wise, this game tops it all. You'll be mashing your number hotkeys and your mouse trying to rid of the monsters trying to swarm you. There are many random traps and surprises lurking in every dungeon and area you face. The skills for each character are also special and will leave you wanting to upgrade all your skills. As said before, each dungeon and area is randomly generated, providing a unique experience everytime you play. You will feel a great sense of accomplishment as you finally knock out the final boss of the game. This then leads to the Mapworks, which you can buy with your in-game currency and play special dungeons. Or you can start up NG+ and start your whole adventure again, keep all your character stats but buffing all item drops and monsters.

All in all, Torchlight II is definitely a game that anyone should check out, even if you do not like RPGs. This game is a must-have on anyone's game list.

reviewText:
Very tight game for its price. It's probably not going to be comparable to Diablo 2, and it's not as deep as PoE for example, but otherwise it's a very polished game that does well in many areas. Compared to Torchlight 1, everything is better.

+ Skill system is better and pretty much all skills have some use now, no more overlapping skills between classes.
+ Areas are just better. Maps are larger and the smaller pieces that make them up are much more different and interesting. It's probably one of the game's greatest highlights. The minigames also add a lot to the randomness.
+ Combat takes more effort than mashing 1 skill at the highest difficulty.
+ Modding.

It has cons but honestly still feels very polished for the price that it doesn't really matter that much.

reviewText: Mkay, so...Torchlight. If you like any of the Diablo games, then chances are you're going to like this game. It's simple enough, really...four classes to choose from, a good array of skills that you can put points into, and the ability to use any weapon in the game, regardless of your class. I think the best part about this game is you can - technically - build yourself how you want, and still have a class that works well even in increased difficulties. Only real problem is that the increased difficulty doesn't net you any rewards. It's just harder. No increased loot drops, nothin'. Heck, you actually get *less* experience points per kill, and everything is made to be more expensive, while you meanwhile get less gold per drop. There's some meh" things about this game
recommended: mods make this game a whole lot better."

reviewText: One of the biggest problems with these Hack 'n Slash / Dungeon Crawler / Lootpocalypse games is the huge piles of loot that you (or at least I) feel compelled to lug back to town every five minutes of combat to sell. And where Dungeon Siege solved this problem with pack mules in singleplayer and ignored the problem in coop, and where Diablo 3 'solved' it by making all the junk loot worthless (people just like seeing lootsplosions, right? They don't like it for the money its worth, that would be silly!), the Torchlight games solved this with an awesome/adorable ferret with goggles that takes your unwanted gear back to town and sells it for you (and I guess they have other animals that can do the same thing or something).\nBesides solving the one flaw of the genre, Torchlight 2 does everything else right (or at least right enough): Online or LAN coop, ferrets with goggles, crazy explosive spell effects, ferrets with goggles, tons of cool loot, ferrets with goggles, random dungeon layouts and ferrets with goggles.\nAs if all of that wasn't enough, they also have ferrets with goggles!

reviewText:
Game: Torchlight 2
Genre: RPG-Adventure
Developer: Runic Games
System: PC (Steam)
Total Score: 92/100
Value Score: 9.2/10

• Story: 7/10
o Torchlight 2's storyline picks off where Torchlight 1 ended. The Alchemist which was one of the main characters from the first game ended up becoming corrupt thanks to the effects of the last game's villain's heart. Now you who will play as a new character will have to hunt him down and save the world from whatever he is planning to. You'll be going through several towns, dungeons and all sorts of terrain to find the Alchemist. The storyline overall is a bit generic but the side stories and side quests and their importance plays a interesting role within the overall game.

• Characters: 7/10
o Characters from the first game do appear in this game but barely do you interact with them, other than that all the enemies in the game and the characters you meet afterwards are all new but do not hold much substance like other RPGs however the amount of characters especially when it comes to enemy designs is quite huge. The player themselves can also create their own character, choosing the gender, skin color, hair appearance and color amongst other tidbits though you would not probably notice a difference due to the fact the armor you get in the game would make it to where you probably would not care about how you make your character look.

• GamePlay: 10/10
o Torchlight 2's gameplay is very similar to Torchlight 1's with a few new additions. For one, you have the choice to play as 4 different classes: Berserker which is best for close quarters combat and has insane speed, Mechanic is which best as a support character and as a secondary attacker, Outlander which is best with long range attacks and finally Ember Mage which is the equivalent of a Wizard in TL2 which is pretty much self explanatory. Depending on what you choose for skills and equipment you can build your character up to different builds and uses such as having a offensive ember mage instead of a magic user. The user interface is very similar to TL1 which is heavily inspired by Diablo and World of Warcraft. You have access to different features in towns and throughout different dungeons such as the ability to gamble for items, power up items through enchantments (which do not break or de-enchant anymore), to fuse items. Along with that the usual item shop, weapon/armor shop, and the special item/magic shop as well. There are a lot of side quests along with the story's main quests. One of the biggest additions to the game from its predecessor is Online Multiplayer, many people have anticipated this feature and wanted so much from the first game will now get to enjoy it in this game as up to 6 players can connect to each other on TL2's public servers or make their own private server via LAN. All items are exclusive to each player, no player will see another player's item or treasure (this is to prevent any disputes for loot).

• Graphics: 10/10
o Torchlight 2's graphical interfaces, environment and character sprites designs are similar to the first game but further improved with using current technologies making it one of the best looking 2Dish helicopter view games ever made.

• Sound: 10/10
o Torchlight 2 uses voiceovers throughout the majority of the game's main storyline, there will be instances where you will hear voices from other npcs and from yourself during dungeon raids. Torchlight 2's sound effects are both a combination of new effects to the game and uses some effects from the first game. The voiceovers are pretty well done for the characters and the sound effects go nicely with the environment and during the action sequences of cutscenes and battles.

• Music: 8/10
o Torchlight 2 uses similar style of music that the first game used, calm soothing orchestral type music is used mostly in the game, most of the parts of the game it has that unique Star Wars like epic feeling in the background whenever you travel the terrain or go through a town conversing with the NPCs. The developers were also kind enough to allow players to actually have access to the full OST of the game via the Game's folder on the PC, so enjoy the whole OST of Torchlight 2 on your portable mp3 player.

• Length: 10/10
o Torchlight 2's length is possibly its second greatest aspect if not the gameplay, the game's main storyline by itself should take you no more than 20 hours and additional 5-10 hours' worth of grinding and side questing on the side. If that isnt enough, you may do multiple playthroughs with friends or with other characters to see the world of Torchlight through different experiences which of course adds massive appealing value to this aspect.

• Replay Value: 10/10
o One of the best things about most western games is the replay value and TL2 is no exception. The Online multiplayer experience by itself adds great value to the replay value through different experiences and difficulties available for you to choose from. Once you finish the game, you get access to a endless random dungeon which takes you to random environments so you can explore thoroughly for additional treasures and other items. Along with that to add even more value, they added a New Game+ which allows you to play the game all over again using the same character but with a more difficulty twist to the gameplay.

• Player Value: 10/10
o Overall Torchlight 2 expands over the first one and improves in pretty much in every way, despite some network issues it may have from time to time, players will surely enjoy the multiplayer experiences and if not they can dabble on the single player experience which like the multiplayer can be experienced through different difficulties. You have a pretty decent customization options for your characters and can easily build up any class in any possible way. The graphical details have improved from the game, the sound effects and music are kept the similar to the first game. Pretty much TL2 consists of all the good aspects of TL1 plus more.

reviewText:
I remember the day when I had bought this game when it was on a Steam sale. I had a couple of dollars left and I wanted to spend the money on something that interested me. I had bought Torchlight II and haven't touched it for quite some time, since I was not an active Steam user back then. When I first played it, I immediately regretted not playing this sooner.

Torchlight II is, to put in the simplest words, an amazing game. The product is a highly polished game with many surprises hidden around every corner.  The world is randomly generated every time you start a new character/start New Game+ on an existing character so every experience will be a highly unique one. The game really gets to the point; you can immediately delve into the fun of clicking on monsters and annihilating them with your weapons/skills.

As is said in many other reviews, the story is definitely lacking. I had attempted to follow the story when I first started playing but ended up not caring for the story at all. If you are into an RPG with a rich story, this game is not for you.

Gameplay-wise, this game tops it all. You'll be mashing your number hotkeys and your mouse trying to rid of the monsters trying to swarm you. There are many random traps and surprises lurking in every dungeon and area you face. The skills for each character are also special and will leave you wanting to upgrade all your skills. As said before, each dungeon and area is randomly generated, providing a unique experience everytime you play. You will feel a great sense of accomplishment as you finally knock out the final boss of the game. This then leads to the Mapworks, which you can buy with your in-game currency and play special dungeons. Or you can start up NG+ and start your whole adventure again, keep all your character stats but buffing all item drops and monsters.

All in all, Torchlight II is definitely a game that anyone should check out, even if you do not like RPGs. This game is a must-have on anyone's game list.

reviewText: A third of the cost of Diablo III for what is easily the better game.  As I write this I've played five or six hours of Torchlight II, but I expect I'll be playing many more, especially with co-op in the mix.  It's an interesting thing.  I always thought I'd hate this game's aesthetic when compared to Diablo III's fire and brimstone, and on top of that assumed Matt Uelmen's compositions were a better fit for darker fantasy, but it all feels quite right here.  And this really is to Torchlight what Diablo II was to Diablo, making it one of the best games to emerge from this particular tradition.

reviewText: Torchlight is a nice hack and slay game with nice graphics. Prepare yourself for bleeding fingers, since the gameplay is mouse-focused.\nIt is amazing that this game was released somehow since it is full of copyright infringements when you compare it to Diablo2, especially campaign-wise. It is a lot better than D2 in many aspects though. I love the pet/inventory system, which is really comfortable. The fact that the map stays the same after you log on, but can be rerolled and the travel options are nice. The different gaming mods are graded well. I really appreciated the detail of cosmetic items and  monster spawns e.g. werewolves jumping from roofs or crawling out of cellars. The quest markers are useful, but quite confusing in outposts sometimes. The skill tree layout is bad and could be way more efficient if you knew what skill supports another without researching online. The story itself is way too short, and the option too repeat it a mio times for additonal achievements only stresses the lack of content. When you play it for the first time and do everything incl. dungeons and cleaning maps the leveling is perfect for the primary quests. You start your NG+ at 50 - no matter what level you are. When you do only the primaries in the NG+ the leveling is not graded, but pre-set, which is really annoying. Although the mapworks enable you to do several extra dungeons and areas it is unclear and you can't seem to trace which ones you have completed and which ones you haven't.\nOverall it is a nice game, but don't expect it to be very entertaining for more than a few weeks in single player. But I would always recomment to play it in multi-player anyway.

reviewText:
Torchlight 2 Review:

For this review I will make an effort to break down and analyze different major aspects of the game.

1: Story
2: Graphics
3. A: GamePlay Mechanics
3  B: Classes
3 C: Loot/Equipment
4: Wrap up and Bonus

1 Story
The Setting of the game takes place directly after the events of torchlight 1, the alchemist has broken out of the ember mine that the entirety of Torchlight 1 has taken place in, and you start your character out just outside a major town that he has already been through.

The vast majority of the Game's story is presented to you through dialogs with the various NPCs that inhabit the area. The actual story itself, in my opinion is nothing special and while they did make a decent effort, ultimately it falls short of really sucking me in. (But lets be honest the story isn't why you play the game is it?) having said that I did appreciate the easter eggs that the developers put in including a reference to a very popular game that came out around the same time that has the same basic formula.

2. Graphics
The game has a bright and colorful world with matching art direction. All the creatures, NPCs and classes look great, a refreshing break from the bleak and demonic tropes that are prevelent throughout the genre. The Spell effects are cool and they don't generally get in the way of seeing the monsters and such.  Since the game has lower system requirements than Diablo 3, and starts out in a lower price point,  the equipment and overall graphics aren't quite as impressive as Diablo 3. But, the graphics overall feel more like diablo 2 than diablo 3 does.

3 A. GamePlay Mechanics
The Combat is fun and depending on the difficulty, requires a lot of careful consideration on how you build and equip your character. I love it. In many ways, I am reminded of diablo 2 in how the mechanics are structured. Its not quite as deep as diablo 3, but I was not expecting that much.  Movement is fluid, and, thanks to the low system requirements it runs at a solid 60FPS on my iMac from 2010.

You have 2 different types of leveling you can do. You can Level up traditionally from gettinng experience which allows you to distribute 5 stat points to whatever you want (instead of them automatically being distributed in diablo 3)

3 B: Classes
The Vanilla game comes with 4 classes, each look and feel completely different from each other. The Embermage starts out weaker than others, but as you unlock new skills you find yourself with a huge grin on your face as you wipe out legions of enemies. Just don't expect to be able to take more than a few hits.  While with the berzerker you go right up close and personal to the enemies attack quickly and annihilate them. The engineer plays more like a tank, with slow deliberate attacks and skills that allow you to summon helpers to attack enemies or to distract enemies from you. Finally, the Marksman focuses on hit and run from  a-far  with skills that allow for those types of tactics. Natually each of the characters has many skills to choose from that allow for alternate tactics. Unlike Diablo 3, or Path of Exile once you choose a skill, you have to pay to reroll the skills up to 3 previous skill points can be refunded.

3 C: Loot/Equipment
The loot and equipment is quite similar to other games in the genre (IE diablo clones), with the standard tropes of rarity (IE normal, magic, rare and unique, and legendary) with increasing number of bonus' to stats depending on rarity. Each Class has two types of unique weaponry, however that doesn't mean you can't equip melee weapons on a mage or on a ranged character.

4. Wrap up:
I was excited for it because several former developers of diablo 2 were heading up this team. I have played a large amount of the game under VMware while I was waiting for the mac native version. and its safe to say that I've gotten my money, your money, and two other people's money's worth out of the game.The thing that REALLY sold it to me was the Mod Support.

5: Mods!
Well you've beaten the vanilla game, thats all well and good but are you ready for the REAL fun to begin? download the Synergies Mod. What does it do? Well for starters, it adds 3 new classes, that all feel  like they belong in the game nearly 700!! new pieces of equipment and weapons, new areas to explore, new enemy types, an end-game and raids. not to mention a rebalancing of the existing skills and classes. I would say that its got more content in it than most expansions's do. I cannot reccomend this mod enough. Unfortunately, there is a maximum of 10 mods per game. (this is gotten around by combining mods into 1 large mod pack) And you cannot play with those who do not have the same mods as you.

6. Rating

In this rating system 5 is average,  which means its plenty good just nothing special, even slightly.

NOTE the scores below are weighted against other games in the genre.

Story: 3/10 There is a story, it ends and has no plot holes. But thats about it.
Graphics: 5/10 While its not super fancy and flashy like its bigger budget siblings, the art direction is pretty good and ages well
Mechanics 7/10 Again, not as deep as bigger budget entries in the genre but still plenty of fun (and mod support really helps with this aspect)
Sound: 8/10 Matt Uleman (the composer of the dIablo 1 and 2 soundtrack) did the soundtrack for this game and you can hear echos of his earlier work, and its glorious.
Combat: 5  out of 10 Its not great but it sure is quite a satisfying experience overall.

reviewText:
Torchlight 2 Review:

For this review I will make an effort to break down and analyze different major aspects of the game.

1: Story
2: Graphics
3. A: GamePlay Mechanics
3  B: Classes
3 C: Loot/Equipment
4: Wrap up and Bonus

1 Story
The Setting of the game takes place directly after the events of torchlight 1, the alchemist has broken out of the ember mine that the entirety of Torchlight 1 has taken place in, and you start your character out just outside a major town that he has already been through.

The vast majority of the Game's story is presented to you through dialogs with the various NPCs that inhabit the area. The actual story itself, in my opinion is nothing special and while they did make a decent effort, ultimately it falls short of really sucking me in. (But lets be honest the story isn't why you play the game is it?) having said that I did appreciate the easter eggs that the developers put in including a reference to a very popular game that came out around the same time that has the same basic formula.

2. Graphics
The game has a bright and colorful world with matching art direction. All the creatures, NPCs and classes look great, a refreshing break from the bleak and demonic tropes that are prevelent throughout the genre. The Spell effects are cool and they don't generally get in the way of seeing the monsters and such.  Since the game has lower system requirements than Diablo 3, and starts out in a lower price point,  the equipment and overall graphics aren't quite as impressive as Diablo 3. But, the graphics overall feel more like diablo 2 than diablo 3 does.

3 A. GamePlay Mechanics
The Combat is fun and depending on the difficulty, requires a lot of careful consideration on how you build and equip your character. I love it. In many ways, I am reminded of diablo 2 in how the mechanics are structured. Its not quite as deep as diablo 3, but I was not expecting that much.  Movement is fluid, and, thanks to the low system requirements it runs at a solid 60FPS on my iMac from 2010.

You have 2 different types of leveling you can do. You can Level up traditionally from gettinng experience which allows you to distribute 5 stat points to whatever you want (instead of them automatically being distributed in diablo 3)

3 B: Classes
The Vanilla game comes with 4 classes, each look and feel completely different from each other. The Embermage starts out weaker than others, but as you unlock new skills you find yourself with a huge grin on your face as you wipe out legions of enemies. Just don't expect to be able to take more than a few hits.  While with the berzerker you go right up close and personal to the enemies attack quickly and annihilate them. The engineer plays more like a tank, with slow deliberate attacks and skills that allow you to summon helpers to attack enemies or to distract enemies from you. Finally, the Marksman focuses on hit and run from  a-far  with skills that allow for those types of tactics. Natually each of the characters has many skills to choose from that allow for alternate tactics. Unlike Diablo 3, or Path of Exile once you choose a skill, you have to pay to reroll the skills up to 3 previous skill points can be refunded.

3 C: Loot/Equipment
The loot and equipment is quite similar to other games in the genre (IE diablo clones), with the standard tropes of rarity (IE normal, magic, rare and unique, and legendary) with increasing number of bonus' to stats depending on rarity. Each Class has two types of unique weaponry, however that doesn't mean you can't equip melee weapons on a mage or on a ranged character.

4. Wrap up:
I was excited for it because several former developers of diablo 2 were heading up this team. I have played a large amount of the game under VMware while I was waiting for the mac native version. and its safe to say that I've gotten my money, your money, and two other people's money's worth out of the game.The thing that REALLY sold it to me was the Mod Support.

5: Mods!
Well you've beaten the vanilla game, thats all well and good but are you ready for the REAL fun to begin? download the Synergies Mod. What does it do? Well for starters, it adds 3 new classes, that all feel  like they belong in the game nearly 700!! new pieces of equipment and weapons, new areas to explore, new enemy types, an end-game and raids. not to mention a rebalancing of the existing skills and classes. I would say that its got more content in it than most expansions's do. I cannot reccomend this mod enough. Unfortunately, there is a maximum of 10 mods per game. (this is gotten around by combining mods into 1 large mod pack) And you cannot play with those who do not have the same mods as you.

6. Rating

In this rating system 5 is average,  which means its plenty good just nothing special, even slightly.

NOTE the scores below are weighted against other games in the genre.

Story: 3/10 There is a story, it ends and has no plot holes. But thats about it.
Graphics: 5/10 While its not super fancy and flashy like its bigger budget siblings, the art direction is pretty good and ages well
Mechanics 7/10 Again, not as deep as bigger budget entries in the genre but still plenty of fun (and mod support really helps with this aspect)
Sound: 8/10 Matt Uleman (the composer of the dIablo 1 and 2 soundtrack) did the soundtrack for this game and you can hear echos of his earlier work, and its glorious.
Combat: 5  out of 10 Its not great but it sure is quite a satisfying experience overall.

reviewText:
Very tight game for its price. It's probably not going to be comparable to Diablo 2, and it's not as deep as PoE for example, but otherwise it's a very polished game that does well in many areas. Compared to Torchlight 1, everything is better.

+ Skill system is better and pretty much all skills have some use now, no more overlapping skills between classes.
+ Areas are just better. Maps are larger and the smaller pieces that make them up are much more different and interesting. It's probably one of the game's greatest highlights. The minigames also add a lot to the randomness.
+ Combat takes more effort than mashing 1 skill at the highest difficulty.
+ Modding.

It has cons but honestly still feels very polished for the price that it doesn't really matter that much.

reviewText:
After the advent of Diablo came the copies and the knock-offs. We all know of them. HOWEVER, I am very happy to announce that Torchlight II is better then any of the Diablo games out there. This can be explained with several things:
1) Torchlight II accomplishes immersion without having to rely on a very dark universe, thus making it more accesible to all types of players
2) Torchlight II has some very interesting class design ideas that allow both flexibility and hardcore focus
3) The combat is frantic but meaningful, every movement means something ( dodging this spell, zoning this enemy, etc.)
4) The items (especially the unique items) provide sustainance for the treasure-hunter hidden deep in all of us

I could go on and on... but I wont because I would rather you try Torchlight II out, rather than continue reading a fanboys shameless confession.

ENVOY RATED: 10/10

reviewText: I used to play Diablo II with my buddies all crammed around a table with a scene from cable management hell running off of and under the table. Over the last few years it's gotten harder to get the group together, meaning on the rare occasions that we were able to we played until someone said uncle twice. Then tragedy. The death of a laptop, the loss of a save file. One of us moved away. It was a dark time. When I found out Torchlight II had online multiplayer (I had played plenty of the first one at this point) I saw light. I still see that light. I mean, only one of my friends has bought it so far, but once the other  shlub buys it it will be like old times. It's not just copy paste Diablo, but the gameplay feels like home in a sexy new environment made for you to mod. You want it. You know you can't stop.

commentsCount: taking you across different continents

column21: but part of the fun is the expiremntation.\nStats and skills are thankfully spelled out in a detailed tooltip. You know what to expect from what you invest in almost down to the modifier that dictates is effectiveness. No more guessing on what stats or gear is essential
column22: but it doesn't hold your hand either as you can play around with what primary stat you want to focus on as a modifier. Vitality is a bit useless if you're not a shield user

reviewText:
Although I am not into fast-paced games, I made a rare exception with Torchlight II and its predecessor.
Why? Well, I like the cute meets gore aesthetics, the beautiful landscapes (but I prefered the first installment’s ’scapes), the responsiveness, the freedom in designing builds, the replayability (the game is subtly different across classes and levels), the music and sound effects, and the accessibility to non-action players like me.
On the other hand, I don’t like the basic storyline, the little mistakes (such as the Mimic and fighting Dessicated Corpse labels a little bigger than they should be), the fishing mini-game, the many useless skills, the sometimes unbalanced fates our characters receive from the RNGod, but those are minor qualms.
All in all, a fine Diablo-like game.

reviewText:
This is probably the only game that I had installed since the very beginning and I haven't yet uninstalled, because I keep coming back over and over to this game. Why, you may ask... Well, the reason is simple: MODS.
The vanilla version of this game is very enjoyable, runs perfectly, looks good, can last for quite a bit, but what makes this game truly shine is the mod support.
Even now, more than 3 years after the release of the game, mods are released and they keep the game refreshing.
I am talking about mods that change difficulty, UI, loots, add classes and anything you can imagine in between, making an already great game, even greater.
Absolutely recommended, don't let this little gem escape your steam library.

reviewText: Mkay, so...Torchlight. If you like any of the Diablo games, then chances are you're going to like this game. It's simple enough, really...four classes to choose from, a good array of skills that you can put points into, and the ability to use any weapon in the game, regardless of your class. I think the best part about this game is you can - technically - build yourself how you want, and still have a class that works well even in increased difficulties. Only real problem is that the increased difficulty doesn't net you any rewards. It's just harder. No increased loot drops, nothin'. Heck, you actually get *less* experience points per kill, and everything is made to be more expensive, while you meanwhile get less gold per drop. There's some meh" things about this game
recommended: mods make this game a whole lot better."

reviewText:
After the advent of Diablo came the copies and the knock-offs. We all know of them. HOWEVER, I am very happy to announce that Torchlight II is better then any of the Diablo games out there. This can be explained with several things:
1) Torchlight II accomplishes immersion without having to rely on a very dark universe, thus making it more accesible to all types of players
2) Torchlight II has some very interesting class design ideas that allow both flexibility and hardcore focus
3) The combat is frantic but meaningful, every movement means something ( dodging this spell, zoning this enemy, etc.)
4) The items (especially the unique items) provide sustainance for the treasure-hunter hidden deep in all of us

I could go on and on... but I wont because I would rather you try Torchlight II out, rather than continue reading a fanboys shameless confession.

ENVOY RATED: 10/10

reviewText: I used to play Diablo II with my buddies all crammed around a table with a scene from cable management hell running off of and under the table. Over the last few years it's gotten harder to get the group together, meaning on the rare occasions that we were able to we played until someone said uncle twice. Then tragedy. The death of a laptop, the loss of a save file. One of us moved away. It was a dark time. When I found out Torchlight II had online multiplayer (I had played plenty of the first one at this point) I saw light. I still see that light. I mean, only one of my friends has bought it so far, but once the other  shlub buys it it will be like old times. It's not just copy paste Diablo, but the gameplay feels like home in a sexy new environment made for you to mod. You want it. You know you can't stop.

It's year 2016 and here is my review:

1. This is the best ARPG game I have ever played and probably the best ARPG game you will play.
2. Progress through game is great and have depth. There are four stats STR, DEX, INT and VIT and they all have huge impact on playstile and progress.
3. Skill trees. Play as you wish.
4. Funny graphics. (If your eyes hurt install graphic and texture mod)
5. Highly modable!!!! Want more easy lot? Install mod. Want more classes? Install mod. There are tons of different classes
6. MODS!
7. Not gender locked.
8. You have pet companion that fights for you and carry items.
9. Enchentments and gems and many different items.

Overall 9/10

P.S. After you finish game in Vanilla state go install Synergie mod.

voteText: Torchlight II is your traditional ARPG that brings a lot to the table compared to first installment. All while paralelling Diablo and Diablo II. The original heroes are present in cameos with new classes taking on the mantle in a larger setting across four chapters. Each said class breaks the mold compared to Diablo II with different ability combinations that can make for some interesting builds. Some more viable than others

column21: but part of the fun is the expiremntation.\nStats and skills are thankfully spelled out in a detailed tooltip. You know what to expect from what you invest in almost down to the modifier that dictates is effectiveness. No more guessing on what stats or gear is essential

reviewText:
This is probably the only game that I had installed since the very beginning and I haven't yet uninstalled, because I keep coming back over and over to this game. Why, you may ask... Well, the reason is simple: MODS.
The vanilla version of this game is very enjoyable, runs perfectly, looks good, can last for quite a bit, but what makes this game truly shine is the mod support.
Even now, more than 3 years after the release of the game, mods are released and they keep the game refreshing.
I am talking about mods that change difficulty, UI, loots, add classes and anything you can imagine in between, making an already great game, even greater.
Absolutely recommended, don't let this little gem escape your steam library.
