reviewText:
First Review
This is a very good game, especially for its price. The combat feels fast and makes you feel like a god........or like a fool when you get a stumble attack.
The story is also quite nice, it sort of copys Diablo 2 and 3, but to me that doesn't matter, the way its told matters. The artistic, hand drawn pictures for the cutscenes suit the cartoonish graphics. The world that I always wondered about is also fully realised in this 2nd installment of Runics games. The quest's aren't as grindy and the quest's that were from the portal guy from Torchligh 1, gone. I reaaally didn't at all like those, it was just grindy whilst the quest's this time are fun and have a story. They also kept the reputation mechanic. All in all a great game, a must buy for avid RPG lovers.

It's been a year or more since I wrote the original review, and I think it's time for an update.
This game is still spendlid, but I have a slightly more varied view on Torchlight 2 than I did before.
The vanilla game is something I definetly appreciate far more now after playing with mods for 30-40 hours, and switching back.

This game has several mechanics which make it stand out for me. Things like the reputation system make it easier to upgrade your skills quicker without making you overpowered and consequently beating the mobs easily.
It also has some of the most satisfying combat I have ever seen in a game. I have not seen or played Diablo 3, but this makes me feel pretty happy as I slaughter dozens of zombies or whatever.
The effects of the weapons, abilities and armour are well made, and most are randomly generated but manage to be intersting and be genuinely nice to find.
The levels are relatively different and varied, and have a large selection of different enemies, abilities and focuses with good art design.

Just buy it whilst it is on sale!

reviewText: Torchlight II is a really good game, but not a great game. It has an endearing art-style that's easy on the eyes, and the gameplay is addictive enough to keep you playing 'till the end (I played about 50 hours by the time I beat it). However, there is nothing about this game that is exceptional or raises the bar. The story isn't deep or engaging, and the world lacks depth. Had the developers expanded the towns and added sub characters to strengthen the plot, then this game could have been a bench mark. The loot drops are well-balanced and look decent, the world is visually appealing, even interesting in some places, and the monsters are well-designed. But beyond the relentless grind, there's nothing much motivating you to keep collecting and throwing away loot 'till the next boss fight, except more loot and boss fights, that is. If you're just looking for a game to help you pass the time without being bored, then it does its job well, but don't expect an engaging story to justify the 50+ hours you may waste playing it. In the end, I feel like I got my money's worth, but only based on what I already kind of expected.

reviewText:
Many dungeon crawlers pride themselves on lootporn. Runic Games realises it's nice to also package in an actual game with your Excel sheet, and manages to build an inviting world with a responsive and satisfying combat system.

The game's story is one of tragic desperation, told across 4 acts, and while I won't spoil anything I suggest you not play this for its storyline, as it doesn't go far nor deep. Don't mistake this for a lack of charm though, as each of the game's environments are colourful and varied. From bright shining deserts to gloomy forests and snowy ... cold places. My eyes were never bored.

The four classes available in the game all have their distinctive styles, but also allow for a large amount of customisation on the player's part. Many different active abilities are available to choose from, which translates to many different ways to play. Within the admittedly limited amount of classes I can almost guarantee anyone will find a build they're comfortable with. A minor point against this is that respeccing is not available in the base game. Modding rectifies this.

Which brings me to my next point: The players. This game has an abundance of that whole consumer-friendliness our industry seems to relish in not caring about. You want mod support? It's in there, ranging from the smallest of tweaks to total conversions. Always online DRM? Don't be so daft, play offline if you like and have a lovely experience. What about LAN? Yeah, LAN support is in, go nuts. Also note the apparent lack of any microtransactions or locked-behind-paywalls DLC. The point I'm trying to make is that if you take the direction of the industry into account when you're considering a purchase, this is definitely not the worst option available.

Lastly, I should point you to its price. This game doesn't exactly break the bank compared to most other releases of this scope. HowLongToBeat.com lists the average main story completion takes around 20 hours, that's not counting the side quests in the field, extra dungeons, mapworks (endgame dungeons) or New Game Plus mode.

So what have we got? A 20ish hour flat story with a pleasing coat of paint, well flowing and varied options for combat, single- online- and LAN play and excellent mod support packed into what is a relatively inexpensive game. If your interest has been piqued I highly recommend you play this game, but if you’re on the fence I suggest having a go with the free demo first.

reviewText:
Torchlight 2 is a game for those that enjoy playing with friends. I'm a sucker for beautiful game art, and T2 gave me
more than enough to take in. It's not over-done, so the creators found a great balance between art and game-play.
The magic system is immersive enough that I found myself feeling really smug whenever I broke out my big spells to
do in a whole room of monsters. It's colourful; the character design is detailed enough to become really fond of your character and be impressed by all the others; and the content-rich world is one that you can get really stuck into. So I would recommend this game to those who want to have some fun with friends, and just enjoy a gorgeous game of adventure, teamwork and amusingly mis-matched armour sets that still manage to make you badass anyway. Enjoy!

reviewText:
It is inevitable to compare this game to Blizzard's hack 'n slash RPG. I would say this would be the poor-man's version of Diablo III, but the truth of the matter is Torchlight II holds it's ground and could even be considered a better game overall, depending on what you're looking for.

Torchlight II brings better loot, better progressions system, mob variety and arguably a better 'end-game'. The only two thing it lacks, compared to Diablo III, is the graphical fidelity (although since the game is done in a cartoonish art-style, it is not immediately noticable) and story.

While Torchlight II manages to win points in the atmosphere department, the story of the Diablo universe offers a much more expanded lore and world to explore. Voice acting, cinematics and sound design are far better than what Torchlight II has. Which is to be expected from a series that started it's roots in indie gaming.

Experience sharing in multiplayer could use some tweaking, but loot is instanced for every player and trading is fully functional for all items you find. A big plus for the game is also mod support, something which Diablo III lacks. The Steam Workshop is sure to increase the life-span of the game, and enchance the experience according to your taste buds.

Despite some of it's shortcomings, it is still one of the better hack 'n slash RPGs out there. Definitely worth your time!

reviewText:
Well, this review is not for those who like this kind of RPGs. Rather, I would pen it down for those few like me who usually hate top down. Well, I love action RPGs - fallout 3, Fallout New Vegas and Skyrim are the among the best single player experiences I can remember. But when it comes to top down, I just used to have a scorn for the genre.
I tried diablo 3, torchlight and torchlight 2 (a torchlight fan) at a friend's house long back. I hated it and never looked towards it for months to come. It is accidentally that I had some $4.00 in my wallet and TL2 was on sale that I purchased it. I wanted to try it again, even though I was 99% sure it won't appeal me.

I was wrong. The game is GREAT. But to realize its greatness, there are three things you must keep in mind:
- Don't think that you are playing an action game. There is very little skill of swiftness on mouse and keyboard required in this game. So, definitely not an action game.
- Play it for at least 15 hours, level up to level 25 and then judge.... things keep on adding, new skills start appearing, interesting scrolls begin dropping out of chests and skilled monsters... it is then that you understand how amazing this game is.
- If you are dying more, it is not that you are not able to deliver enough clicks-per-second, it just means that each of the clicks has an ignorantly cascaded set of skills behind it. So, activate the right skills and wear the right armor. I started learning new things about the mechanics when I was 3 hours into the game and am learning totally new things till now (e.g. For torchlight 2 players - sets of armor... the purple thing written in some armor's description... something I learnt at mty 29th hour).

I played the game for 15 hours on normal, realized that I was very ignorant about the game's mechanics, deleted my character, started a veteran character and adorned it with better perks this time... continuing with it.... glad that I started the game again..

HAPPY GAMING!

reviewText:
Great value for the price. Torchlight 1 was a lot of fun, and TL 2 is a sequel done right, improving on all aspects. Along with online co-op, LAN and offline singleplayer, plus a rich modding scene, this is a solid offering.

The combat is so much fun, as is the looting. Mmmm loot, so much loot. Pets are great. Skill trees and all the different kinds of weapons. And it's so gibby and gory, just as it should be.

reviewText:
A quick preface:
I extremely dislike Perfect World Entertainment. After having worked with them many years as a consumer attempting to enjoy some of their products, I find it difficult to recommend anything that they oversee. This is a word of caution, stranger.

With the negativity out of the way...! Torchlight II is a sublime game. Colorful and vivid visuals mesh with professional sound quality and gameplay design features. I have put plenty of time and effort into the game and can easily recommend it to gamers looking for a 'classical' experience.

Torchlight II is an action role-playing game not unlike the Diablo franchise. Immerse yourself in a fantasy world rife with conflict and unique people, places, and ideas. Play one of four classes and then embark on a journey to customize your character even further with three skill trees for each of the archetypes. Bring friends along, tackle procedurally generated dungeons, and advance in the engaging storyline as a casual gamer or passionate 'min-maxer'.

Torchlight II is an exceptional game that can keep you occupied for hours, if not days.... perhaps weeks!

reviewText:
I guess people might say this is just more of the same, but in my opinion, it's way better than the first one. Maybe it's because of it's open world nature, or the better loot, I'm not sure. After having played Diablo 3 I can tell you guys I had more fun playing this.

The graphics are colorful and dark at the same time, which looks extremely good in motion. There are a lot of sidequests, more diverse and usable loot, fishing (of course), pets, skill trees, secrets, randomly generated levels, you name it. So yes, in a way it's more of the same, but at the same time it's much more polished and has a higher fun factor than the first one, and D3.

Finishing everything could take you 20+ hours, but most of us will probably finish it around 14-16 hours. And then there's New Game+...

What I basically mean is; Torchlight II equals fun !

[Rating: 89/100]

reviewText:
I'll put it simply. Unless you've absolutely hated every hack-n-slash action-rpg from Diablo to Titan Quest, you owe it to yourself to buy this game.

While Diablo 3 tried to reinvent the genre with World of Warcraft design philosophies, Torchlight 2 takes an entirely different approach; They have taken all of the elements people loved about previous games in the genre, such as character building, generous piles of loot, and fast action-packed gameplay, perfected those elements and expanded upon them. The result is a true spiritual successor to the games many of us sank countless hours into.

Strapped for cash? It's only $20. Lousy internet? There's Offline and LAN play. Crummy computer? It's so well optimized, you could run it on a laptop. Anything you don't like about the game? It FULLY supports modding and the steam workshop.

reviewText: Do you like Diablo I & II? This game is true Diablo III. I'm not saying that Blizzard failed to deliver good game, but this one is just as much Diablo-like as you can get. Everything from music to combat mechanics just feel like Diablo. Well, music on its own is beast. You can hear same tones as in diablo I & II. Game itself is quite long and has huge replayability, but combined with full mod support it's nearly unlimited. I recommand using Synergies mode as it makes game a lot more difficult as well as adding many new enemies, locations, items, very hard raids and recreates some of existing classes as well as adds some new. In fact only bad thing in TL2 is that it's not really hard, even on highest difficulty it's bit easier than Diablo II. 11/10, would buy again.

reviewText:
10/10 - As a fan of the original Torchlight, I was eager to try out this release and have not been disapointed!  With immersive game play and endless character customisations Torchlight II is highly addictive.  As many other reviews have mentioned, if you are a lover of Diablo II then give this game a shot.

My favourite feature in Torchlight is the unique pet system; you chose from a wide selection of strong companions with customisable gears and skills.  These companions are very functional and an important support tool.  They can be fed different food (that you fish yourself from ponds discovered throughout the game) which morph your pet into different creatures that provide various stat bonuses for a limited period of time.

Well made, no problems at all with bugs etc.

reviewText: All around excellent ARPG.  Great build variety between the classes.  You have control of stat point and skill point distribution making some level of commitment necessary.  Once you finish the story, you can do either NG+ which is similar to how Diablo used to handle Nightmare, Hell, etc, or use the random map room where you can open portals to random dungeons with random enemies with random properties scaled to your level.  There's a lot of replayability here especially considering some of the excellent mods available through the workshop.  I haven't tried PvP, but co-op is fun and easy to start up.

reviewText:
This is all what Diablo 3 should have been, gameplay-wise. reviewText:
What to say about this game, except that it's probably the best Diablo-like you can find ? If you like the A-RPG genre, this game's for you.

The true power of this game is the mods. You can customize your experience as you wish, add new quests, new dungeons, items, recipes, rules, even classes.


There are 2 small drawbacks tho :
- If you liked Diablo for its art design, the cartoonish style here may not totally be of your taste.
- If you like getting 100% of the achievements in your games, there are 4 broken achievements here, and some of the working ones are really annoying and long to get.

Overall, I'd rate this game 8.5/10 as is. With the community backing it up, it goes up to 9.3/10. I love it.

reviewText: If you liked Diablo 2, you'll love this game. While the story and composition are almost exactly identical to D2, there are a few changes that I absolutely loved. I found the skills very approachable, you can make your build as simple or as complex as you want, and most builds are effective. You can no longer upgrade gems the same way, so you don't need to feel compelled to collect and keep all the gems. They added a limited ability to respec your character, so you have a few levels to play around with skill choices, which I found useful. However, the most notable change (for me) is the independent treasure drops. There is no longer a mad scramble for the best loot if you play multiplayer. You can take all the loot you see, which made multiplayer infinitely more enjoyable for me.

reviewText: good hack n slash
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was headed towards a dungeon to complete a quest, ended up exploring the whole map, killed all the mobs, searched for the golden key to open the golden chest, went through a random portal which reserved me a side mission and finally started the dungeon.

Seriously you won't see the time pass in this game, there is a lot to do.

Pros:
-Interesting bosses/monsters.
-Complex itemization (many stats, enchantments, etc).
-Multiple things to do (quests (dungeons, secret rooms, bosses), sidequests (mazes, mini bosses, etc) and other random stuff to do (fishing, gambling,etc).
-Fun game to play with friends (if you're playing with multiple friends, play on elite or else it will be too easy).
-Good combat system. In general, you can't simply spam click to clear mobs, the game pushes you to dodge abilities, manage your mana pool and react to different scenarios (use abilities to trap big guys, use your escape ability to..well escape,etc).

Cons:
-The story is bad, this is definietly not the game to play for its story. To be honest, I stopped caring about the story very early on.
-Can get a bit repetitive.
-Okay character custimization (character creation allows you to play very little with your character's features).

8/10, great game to pick up when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Torchlight II is cheap, fun, and addicting what's not to love about that?

+ Beautiful Visuals: Torchlight II probably offers one of the most broad color palettes of any game ever with maybe the exception of Borderlands 2, the visuals are simple yet beautiful and stand apart from most other games in their own way.
+ Wonderful loot system: Being a huge fan of ARPGs (Diablo in particular) I can't help but love any game mechanic that showers me with items whenever I make something explode, this is a game that makes you work hard for those hard to find items but when you finally get them it makes it all worth it.
+ Multiplayer: The multiplayer in Torchlight is wonderful and features a drop in drop out system so regardless of what level or what part of the campaign you're playing you can join your friends at any time. The game's single player is fun so throw in three buddies (Seven friends with a mod) and it's a blast a little hectic but still alot of fun.
+ Accessable difficulty: I personally hate games being overly difficult that's just my personal opinion, I don't play games to be frustrated I play games to have fun so I was quite pleased when I found out that Torchlight has multiple difficulties ranging all the way from easy to rediculous there's something for everyone.
+ System requirements: PC has a TON of great games, running all of them is a different story and the variety of great games with low system requirements grows smaller by the day it's nice that a game that is as much fun as Torchlight is can be enjoyed by pretty much anyone with a PC.
+ Mods: Since it's release Steam has opened the Steam Workshop to it which has infinitely expanded it's gameplay it's options at this point are rather limitless.

- Visually messy multiplayer: I personally don't have this problem but I've read about people complaining that multiplayer becomes visually 'messy' with multiple players so it's something to keep in mind if you're buying this to play with other people.
- Sometimes loot drops feel slightly disproportionate: Sometimes it feels like loot drops from average enemies are just as lucrative as boss loot drops.
- Story is pretty weak: Not that Torchlight is known for it's outstanding story but yeah it's pretty weak here.

Torchlight is a wonderful bargain and overall an enjoyable experience that I suggest everyone try at least once.

8.5/10

Reasonable Price Point: This game has been a bargain since day one and it has a wonderful development team I would say at least $30 USD.

reviewText: This has to be one of my favorite games of all time!  If you enjoy games that are simple yet in-depth, Intense but relaxing, and just an all round good time, then this is the game for you. Torchlight 2 is a dungeon crawler lootfest and it never gets old!  The four main classes are all amazingly put together and balanced, not to mention the countless number of user created classes and mods out there to make your experience even more unique and exciting. I reccomend this game to everyone. The only con i can think of is that it gets a bit grindy in some parts, but that doesnt hold this game back from being great and one of my favorites!

reviewText:
Incredible game. I wouldn't say it's simpler than the likes of Diablo or Path of Exile, but it is easier to manage. The art style is a bit more cartooney, but in a very good way. Very detailed landscape, diverse items, and intriuging story if you choose to pay attention to it. My favorite part about this game has to be the pet system. You have a battle companion with its own gear, its own inventory, and the ability to recall to town to clear up some inventory space and bring you any basic goods (potions,scrolls, or dynamite) from the store. Makes it much easier to full clear dungeons without having to waste time towning.

I haven't even delved into the multi-player yet, and I'm only on act II of my first character. But this game is already becoming a favorite.

For fans of hack & slash, it's a must-have. For fans of RPG it's a must-have. For fans of loot it's a must-have. For fans of fun, it's most definitely a must-have.

10/10

reviewText:
So, Torchlight II is the continuation of the Torchlight series released back in 2009 by Runic Games. This game is a sequel to the first Torchlight game made.

Plot: The story is pretty simple and easy to follow, it was pretty memorable, it had memorable boss fights and references to other games that they put in such as Vyrax's tower and the Dragon Shrine, which is a huge reference to The Elder's Scrolls IV: Skyrim. The game in my opinion is quite entertaining, although it could be a little too short for some hardcore RPG players as looking at other games for example the Diablo series and so, but personally I also agree that the story itself is a little too short, even though there are things that allowed you to just continue playing this game over and over again.

Gameplay and Multiplayer: With multiplayer added to the Torchlight universe, compared to the first game that didn't have any elements of multiplayer, really did open up new windows for people to really play this game. Also with the addition of the games being moldable, multiplayer has been as fun as ever since it is also a drop-in/drop-out type which does not affect the storyline whatsoever, but with more players in the game the hostile enemies will get a little tougher which could be hard for some people, but in general it does not affect the single player gameplay at all.

Visuals: One word-- Polished". The game looks great and really amazing. It was detailed
date: beautiful and fun to look at even if they were cartoonish and not as realistic as many of the games out there
recommended: they are really well done. As for the cut-scenes
hoursPlayed: they still hold back the elements from Torchlight 1
voteText: which retained the uniqueness and credibility of Torchlight
helpfulPercent: which I believe this game is perfect for most audiences that enjoy games that maybe aren't too realistic.\n\nAudio: The OST is made by Matt Uelmen
votesHelpful: the composer and sound designer of the Diablo series
votesTotal: also joined with Max Schaefer
votesFunny: the same people who made the music for the first Torchlight game. Although the soundtrack really differs in theme from the soundtrack of the Diablo series
commentsCount: they did a really amazing job of implementing the country music themes which gave it a distinctly different sound from the "Tristram" them of Diablo which made it great. They also did an amazing job in this part as they recorded over 200 live takes using a twelve string guitar alongside with many other instruments. The voice acting in this game casted many veteran voice actress and actors such as Lani Minella and so on who performed many of the voices in-game.\n\nReception: This game scored slightly more than the original Torchlight
column16: which most of the reviews received were very favorable. On review sites such as Metacritics
column17: this game attained an overall score of 88 out of 100 based on many reviews from 65 professional gaming critics worldwide which is an amazing score. Would you buy this game? Many RPG players would probably think that this game will just be like the first Torchlight and therefore result in a quick 'hiatus' from playing the game due to the repetitive nature of the game
column18: however this is different. The developers themselves released tools for the players to be able to mod the game as they please
column19: and people who join any multiplayer servers with mods on them will be able to access the mods freely
column20: which leaves the game always moldable and playable in its own unique manners all the time."

reviewText:
What I like:
+ enjoyable co-op gameplay
+ good character and skill design
+ beautiful environment
+ atmospheric music
+ intensive battles
+ steampunk-like elements
+ pet who sells the loot and brings potion while I slay monsters
+ LAN support
+ steam workshop for additional content

What I miss (from the original game):
- a deep story
- memorable NPCs
- shared loot
- respec option
- complex fishing (it is fun for a few times but becomes quite repetitive and I don't get s***)
- portable Deckard Cain for identifying items

Conclusion:
One of the best hack'n'slash multiplayer games. You will gladly replay it even after a year with the same or a new character. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
This is perhaps one of the best point-and-click fantasy RPG games I have had the pleasure of playing. Not only are there different difficulties and online, a massive selection of pets, multiplayer servers that host up to six players at a time, but the story line and characters are highly interesting.
There are four classes to choose from, a mage, an engineer, a gun-slinger, and the classic bezerker. Each has their own special trait that makes each unique and desirable to different types of players. Choosing a class doesn't limit you to their stereotypical equipment, though! Being a dual axe-weilding Embermage and being questioned about  why  I use axes instead of a staff or wand is just a portion of the fun!
I am what I presume to be about one-third of the way through the game judging by level and achievement progress, though I intend to continue playing after I complete the game with my current character. Perhaps the biggest problem I'm facing is my pet hawk being so much more powerful than me. then again, I suppose I am the one that taught it such powerful spells and provided stat-boosting equipment in the form of a collar and tags.
One of my most recent side quests had me help a man recover masks in an attempt to bring peace to two warring races, and though I won't spoil all the details, it was a perfect, Plot twist!!!" moment that had me grin and facepalm at my want to help (And need for xp!)  He turned out to be evil and needed the masks to gain power. Whoopsies! Was fun defeating him though~

Overall
date: I would suggest this game to anyone that enjoys RPG-style games that finds others hard to run due to system requirements. The minor issues I experience are not enough to subtract from the experience and pleasure of this game. A 9.5/10"

reviewText:
Bear in mind i haven't played the first one, Torchlight 2 is a absolute blast to play. The visuals/setting is stunning, the different colours are lush and vibrant and the characters designs are great. Gameplay is nothing special, as i played the game and finished my playthrough using nothing but clicks. But it's what you expect from a genre like this, so i'm not complaining. The pet system was excellent, as it saves me the trouble from having to run back and forward to the nearest town. Playing with a friend was great, and had a very minor exception of a connection issue, but that easily could have been on my part.

A very great game to have overall.

reviewText:
Best ARPG I've played to date. Why?

- Casual gamer Friendly!

- Although there is, what may seem at first, a limited number of classes the skill selection makes for at least 3 or 4 different sub-variations for each class. Replay value is great, although leveling is a test of patience. Capping taking roughly 2 complete playthroughs.

- Graphics are not as hard on the average CPU that us mortals can afford. I prefer stylized graphics over realistic graphics because they are never out of style or look dated like most other 3D games.

- It offers an Endgame consisting of Mapworks, a tool that allows you to run random dungeons of a level of your choosing (up to 105), and Tarroch's Tomb, a relentless 10 wave gauntlet that drops loot every wave you beat but disappears if you die (Wave 1 comprised of lvl 100 enemies and wave 10 of lvl 199 enemies).

- The loot system actually feels FAIR!!! *coughs* Diablo III *coughs*

- Moddability adds heaps to the game including a difficulty increase and class changes that increase replay value. Downside is modded game saves are different than stock and you can only play with people that have the same mods. Items can not be crossed from modded to unmodded.

- If you get bored or just want to test limits you can duplicate items for money or utility by using a stash and save file manuever. You could also use console to spawn items but you will be labeled as a cheater. The ability to do these cheats adds a lot to the experienced of a gamer that is NOT HARDCORE. Casual gamers need to be catered to too.

The only real downside I found was the relentlessness when making ability choices.
MARK MY WORDS: You cannot respec more than the last 3 abilities you leveled or chose. This means you must level up a character from scratch to try a different build and will probably have to make 2 almost identical characters to fix a stupid choice mistake you made on your first try at a class. Some people love this feature but I believe it would be better if you could just have 2 sub-class slots like you have in WoW or if you could get an option to reset points after completing the game. Just my 2 cents.

Please buy this and enjoy.

reviewText:
Torchlight II is basically the original game's Diablo 2, and it bares at least a dozen or so different parallels to those two games. From having an overworld, to all the classes being balanced toward each other's weaknesses, to the goal of the game being to slay the evil incarnation of the protagonist of the previous game. And my god is it awesome.

Let me be blunt and say that this game's marketing strategy was amazing. The developer basically had to do next to nothing to market the game, since it was entirely carried by the fact it addresses basically every complaint people had with Diablo 3 in one fell swoop. It has no always on DRM, it has mods, local access network multiplayer and online and the list just goes on and on. It's a complete game from start to finish and like every Diablo-esque game, you're a sociopathic hero who simply just carves through entire armies worth of enemies like a hot knife through butter.

This is by far one of the greatest sequels I've ever played.

reviewText: You know that old game you used to play that is no longer supported by the company that originally made it.  You know, that one that spent countless hours dungeon crawling through with you guild and friends.  This is the game that brings what was once lost back to us with gusto!  This have multiple options that make it a real bonus among the Diablo set, because not only do you a great game with a great story, but you also get probably one the best sets of expandable content through steam.  Setting up you account for online access through Runic Games is a little odd, but once done, you have access to all your friends on steam and many different options to play.  If you looking for replayability, this is the game for you, well worth your money to pick this up! RUNIC games did an outstanding job creating what reallly outdoes anything they have done before.

reviewText:
Sometimes a game of this type comes along and does so many things right, that it's hard to say anything bad about it.
If you like Diablo style fun this game will blow your mind!
The Dungeons are fun, the classes are great and the world is fluid and lovingly crafted. Immersion never feels forced in Torchlight 2!
You'll find yourself playing this game to realise your characters maximum potential for your chosen style of play/build, and then putting it to the test. Personally I get a giggle every time I send my pet to to town to sell the crap I've laden  it's bag with, such a great feature that, which means you can get on with your killing (if you dare going alone!).
And when you're done, you can get content from the Steam Workshop to extend your game play, and even add 3+ more classes, more dungeons, and even raids! Hell, if you're into content creation and a little know-how, you can get the GUTS tool and make your own!

Once you're set up to play on-line you can play your game either on LAN or Internet, and your friends can join you in your adventure, and trade goodies to each other!

There is a small hassle setting up an on-line account and linking it to your steam account on the game website, and then add friends so you can play on-line with them. It's nothing hard, but I've heard the picky few complain xD.
If you're playing in Mod Mode (Steam workshop addons), you have to make sure your friends are running the same ones, in order to play together, otherwise it's pretty straightforward :D

Personal Rating: Great Game, worthy of any library
Score Rating: 92% - Nearly a Classic!
